text:
Now I'd like to introduce today's
speakers from right to left. Kara Scoggin, who you will be hearing from
later today, is the senior communications

manager of Stanford Center for
Professional Development, responsible for advancing student engagement inside and
outside of Stanford.

Today's featured presenters
are Kenji Hakuta, Jeff Zwiers and

Sara Rutherford-Quach. Sara, a former bilingual elementary
teacher has more than 13 years of

experience working with the linguistically
diverse students and their teachers, and has conducted extensive research
on instructional practices for

English learners. Sara was previously awarded
a National Academy of Education Spencer Foundation
Dissertation Fellowship for

her work on the role of silence and speech in an elementary classroom
serving language minority students.

Her areas of interests include classroom
discourse and interaction analysis,

language, culture, and instruction in
multilingual and multicultural educational

environments, institutional policy and
curricular change and educational equity.

Sara has been involved with the design and teaching of more than 20
MOOC offerings since 2013.

And she has also directed the development
of many learning modules with the smarter balance assessment consortium and
the ELPA21 consortium.

Jeff has worked for more than 15
years as a professional developer and instructional mentor in
urban school settings,

emphasizing the development of literacy,
thinking and academic language for linguistically and
culturally diverse students.

He has published books and articles on
reading, thinking, and academic language. His most recent book is
Academic Conversations: Classroom Talk

that Fosters Critical Thinking and
Content Understandings. His current work at the Center to
Support Excellence in Teaching focuses

on developing teachers, core practices for
teaching academic language,

comprehension of complex text, and oral
communication skills across subject areas.

And Kenji Hakuta is active
in education policy.

He has testified to Congress and courts
on language policy, the education of language minority students, affirmative
action in higher education, and

improvement of quality
in educational research. Kenji is an elected member of
the National Academy of Education,

a fellow of the American Educational
Research Association, and a fellow of the American Association for
the Advancement of Science, recognized for

his accomplishments in linguistics and
language sciences. He has served on the board
of various organizations,

including the Educational Testing Service,
the Spencer Foundation and

the New Teacher Center. Now I'd like to turn
the floor over to Kenji.

>> Good morning everyone, and
thank you for taking the time and on a nice summer day to join us today for
our presentation about

the course that we'll be offering,
Rich Talk = Rich Learning. And I'm pleased to be opening up
this presentation with my colleagues
Jeff Zwiers and Sara Rutherford-Quach.

To begin,
I'd like to view a video of a classroom, an ELD or an English language development.

They're in parts of countries called
English as second language or it was the new language class,
of fourth grade students who are having

conversation having just read
The True Story of The Three Little Pigs. And after reading,

students are discussing as a prompt
whether the wolf was guilty or not. And so I'm going to play this video.

>> The big bad wolf is not guilty
because he was baking a cake for

his grandma and
he had a really bad cold and he blowed the house down by
accident because he had a cold.

>> So what you're saying is the big
bad wolf isn't guilty because he was trying to make a cake for his grandma and
he had a really bad cold and

he needed sugar to go get. And he accidentally sneezed down
the houses because he had a cold.

>> Yes, that was what I was saying. >> The big bad wolf is guilty because
what if he sneezed on purpose?

And what if the pigs weren't able
to sneeze it down, I mean to sneeze down the house, and he made up his own
story, and he made it all planned?

>> So what you're saying is that
the Big Bad Wolf is guilty,

because he might have
sneezed on purpose and blown the house down on purpose and

the pigs are [INAUDIBLE]
>> What I mean is he's doing

it on purpose because I
think he made his own

story to make all the big
bad things align.

>> So, you're saying is that
he made up the whole story. So, he doesn't want to go to jail.

>> So now just having watched that video, let's just talk about why
the role of rich talk and

rich learning in this conversation
that we just observed.

And then ask really questions
about the fundamental role of language in
classroom as students learn.

One is that students
are wired to interact, that

really the role that language plays
is in facilitating interaction.

But what you really saw in the video
was two students who were really interacting about the prompt of whether
the big bad wolf was guilty or not.

Why or why not? Sharing ideas and so forth. And it's something that you hope
to see in a lot of classrooms and

that's why we showed it and
this is really the purpose of course is to try to promote
instructional strategies for

supporting students being able to
engage and interact in this way. And one of the things we hope
to show you in the video, and

those of you who saw it probably witnessed
this, might think back to the video and

saying okay, this is really what
language is about for kids. It's not about repeating vocabulary words.

It's not about struggling to find
the correct tense on a verb. It really is about interacting and
engaging with others.

Another question you might ask of this
video, if you had to think about this was,

were there opportunities for
students to think on their feet? A conversation is not about scripted,
going back and forth, reading sentences.

But it really is about
spontaneous listening to others, thinking about what the other said, and

trying to formulate your own ideas
relative to what the other person said.
And it is a live animal so to speak.

It's also an opportunity
to try out ideas that, a conversation is wonderful
because not everything

is transcribed, and
you're not held accountable for
it except during the immediate moment. So it's a great time to try out ideas.

What you think about this? Or this is what I'm thinking,
and so forth. So that spontaneity and
trying out ideas is

another important
component of conversations. Another is around clarifying ideas and
sometimes others will help you,

because they will say not quite
sure what you said there. Or is this what you mean?

And that allows you to sharpen your own thinking by just by
sort of putting the words out there.

This conversation is also another way in
which you can try to support your ideas.

Ideas are complex. They are, whether you're guilty or
not, is a complex

idea and you may find multiple
ways to try to support that. And so these are the sorts of things that,
at least those of you who saw the video,

probably saw that
the students struggling with. A lot of this is around language being,
it's a biological thing.

It's something that's alive,
it's spontaneous, it's creative.

And these are the kind of
elements of conversation. I'm going to ask Sara and Jeff if you might want to comment on some
of what you might have seen in the video.

>> This is Jeff. I'd like to zoom in on clarifying ideas.. What you will see or what you might have seen in
the video is a lot of paraphrasing.

And paraphrasing, even though it seems
like it's just repeating things,

it's a powerful way for kids to both get
feedback on how clear their ideas are.

But it's also a way to build
language as I clarify your idea,
or as I paraphrase your idea. I'm practicing with the language.

So it's an authentic way
to practice language
when you're in a conversation with others.

>> Sara, you want to add anything that. They're having a conversation
here by the way. >> [LAUGH]
>> And

it really is about how we develop
our thinking and develop language. >> [LAUGH] One thing I wanna add, and
this kind of encompasses all of this.

Is that all of these things or
even conversation moves or are trying to get students to paraphrase.

You can try these things out but
at the heart of it, if your classroom does not have a culture
where it's okay to make mistakes and

it's okay to say things that aren't
exactly the polished final results,

then a lot of these
things will be difficult. And so one of the things that we're
trying to do in this course and

in this webinar is that we're trying
to build a culture of conversation. But also a culture where

Knowledge is something that's
generated throughout time. And you don't just ask and
answer questions.

You ask a question and
they come back with an answer. So the idea of conversations is that
they're building towards an answer, and

they're working on it. And so that's one of the things
that if that's not there, then all of these different
points are hard to do.

So I want to make sure that we mention
that as we move on because that's kind of at the heart of what this building
a culture of classroom conversation is.

>> Great, thank you. And this really, the idea of conversation
as being the way in which content,
thinking and language come together. Think of them as sort of a macrame or

blending together of these is really what
we were hoping to promote in this course.

And the context for this work,
and Sara and Jeff and I and others on our team have been working for
the last three years now.

Offering free online courses, MOOCs, trying to experimenting
around with this idea.

And part of what motivated us to do
this work was because of the shifts in

standards that were going
on around the country. Some of them called our call the Common
Core in English, language arts and math.

Many states call them college and
career ready standards. But all of them are are really
related standards in that

they're really trying to promote deeper,
more rigorous,

uses of language in the course of
learning English language arts skills,

as well as mathematical skills. And states that have
adopted the next generation

science standards or
similar variations on science.

A lot of them require
collaborative language. They require argumentation.

They require engagement and explanation of one's reasoning
around complex texts and so forth.
And so that's what we're trying to gain.

And a lot of the shifts
really require a move from

thinking about the language
being used as an individual

accumulating of the right answers,
"paying" for points, or playing school.

And rather the actual
engagement with language in the course of collaborative
conversations that are happening.

And so what we want to see is
less of this kind of formulaic

repetitive kinds of uses of language and
more around collaborating, understanding, building, using and
communicating whole ideas.

That these new requirements for
how we should really think about

engaging students in rigorous content
that's supported by the shift in the standards towards
college career ready standards,

really requires this kind of more organic,
more rich,
collaborative, dyadic or group conversational uses of language.

So I'm going to now
shift this over to Jeff,

who is going to elaborate further on
what we'll be doing in this course.
>> Jeff here, and I want to start off with looking at, there are a lot of fake or
inauthentic conversations out there.

And here's a nice quotation
by a philosopher I believe.

The more genuine conversation is, the less it's conduct lies within
the will of either partner...

A conversation has a spirit of its own,
and the language in which it is conducted
bears its own truth within it.

That is, it allows something him
to emerge which henceforth exists. So in a conversation,
two people bring their ideas.

But they're not just memorized, and they're not just one person sharing their
idea with the other, they build something.

And so that's what we're trying
to get out in the classroom, is how can students work with each other
to construct ideas in conversation.

And, but as Sara eluded to earlier,
we also have to

foster some conversational
mindsets in our students.

It's not just teachers doing things. It's also students need to unlearn
a few things, and need to learn that

conversation and working with others can
be a powerful way to learn many things.

And so
here's a semi-humorous slide although, there's a non humorous element to it.

If you look at it, what we'd like you to
just each time with a topic is introduced, for example, today will begin our
unit on the American Revolution.

Every student thinks, and this is where
you can start laughing if you want, but I can't wait to share my ideas and
hear those of others.

You know you're probably thinking how many
students actually think that and then. I'll learn and
remember this better by talking about it.

Now there might be a certain
few kids that might think that, because they like to talk, but
we're not as concerned about those kids.

I like it when partners push me to think,
build and clarify. Yeah, and I'm not sure how many kids I
know, and I'm open to changing my mind and
learning new ideas from others. And so these types of mindsets make

up the culture of conversation, and the
culture of learning through conversation.

Actually if you look at this, I sometimes wonder how many adults
in different settings have these.

And what we want,
we want our students to grow up into adults that also have these
types of mindsets right.

That they're not just individual competing
with others and just learning on my own.

And so that's one of the things that
we try to emphasize in our work.

Let's look at, another area important
area is looking at the prompts,

this is come up in our ongoing
research that we do with teachers related to our online courses and
other work.

And we've found that there's a big
struggle to come up with effective prompts, and so a couple things
that we'll cover it briefly here.

One is having a purpose for conversing. A lot of kids and adults don't
often know why they're talking,

don't have a solid purpose or direction. There's also, the prompt should require
thinking and doing something with ideas.

So, not just regurgitating, but
actually transforming ideas in some way, transforming, fortifying,
that kind of thing.

And then finally, they should encourage
students to share novel ideas and learn from one another,
like we said earlier it's not just

I'm sharing my wisdom with you, and you're
just agreeing and nodding your head. So there's a building, there's I bring
some materials to the conversation,

you bring some materials, and then we both construct something that
we couldn't have done on our own.

And now let's look at some sample
prompts and we'll see how these do.

What's the most important theme for
fourth graders in this story? Does that hit all the boxes here?

If there is a purpose,
I might have a different idea than you. They require thinking, definitely this
type of interpretive thinking, and

each kid might have a novel idea, even if they have the same theme in their
mind as they come to the conversation.

There's different reasons for it and
different ways of expressing it. Often there's going to
be different evidence.
How about.

What conclusions can we make about animal
adaptations based on this evidence? So it's a science prompt.

Does it have a purpose? Yes. Does it require thinking? Yes. Does it encourage students
to share novel ideas?

In most cases, students will be
able to share novel ideas and have them synthesize and combine together.

How about, collaborate to create
a real world word problem

that requires both adding and
subtracting of fractions.

So this also, there's a purpose,
they're constructing something, it requires thinking, because they have to
apply some of the thinking that they've

been doing in other
probably similar problems. And it encourages them to share some novel
ideas about what kind of problem we're

gonna create together. And then finally,
another example, would be.

Was Christopher Columbus a hero or not? And this is a common topic
in a lot of schools and

what I like to do is,
does this does it have a purpose? Yes.

Does it require thinking? And does it encourage students
to share novel ideas? And what I'd like to do is
look at again look at these.

Let's see if the prompt actually
works with this little snippet of a conversation.

Okay, so it's the same prompt. I don't think Columbus was a hero. Why not? Cuz he hurt them and
made them to be slaves.

But he helped Spain get rich and
he found America. So?
He hurt them. Heroes don't hurt or make slaves. Maybe. But he was brave to keep sailing.
He had maps. And he met a Portuguese guy. That guy should be famous, not Columbus.

Okay, so did the prompt work? And that's one of the questions
that we wanna continue to ask as we

work with conversations. The conversations are extremely messy,
especially paired conversations.

You have 15 to whatever conversations
going on simultaneously.

It's a messy business. It's loud and you can only listen to a few
at a time when you're in the classroom.

So, we have to really
get our prompts right. And, that's one of the things
that we try to work on.

How can we come up with prompts? Of course, there's a lot that
leads into that prompt as well. There's a lot of things that kids need
to learn, like about the Portuguese guy.

But, we want kids to learn things and
then be able to share them in these conversations, because a lot, it's almost
like a foundry where they're adding

things and they're coming up with new
things, or adding their own ideas and then they're coming up with new things
in this foundry of conversation.

conversation. I'm gonna pass it on to Sara now.

>> Okay, so this is a great segue because

how forming a thoughtful prompts that
engenders conversation is really important.

And not necessarily
a problem that just ask for a single answer or a series of answers.

But that is important,

And what we mean by that is basically listening to
current student conversations.

Where your students are right now. Or if it's a summer,
where other students are right now.

And then thinking about,
where you'd like them to be?

So a lot of you and when I was

So I taught kindergarten and

three, four times on the carpet
while we were there. But I didn't necessarily know
what they were all saying and

I couldn't, because there was 1 of me and
20 different kids, so there's 10 different conversations going on, or I hope there's
10 different conversations going on.

So one thing that we really advocate for
is really focusing in on one or two conversation, recording those
conversations and listening to

the recording and transcribing it so that
you can really tell what kids are saying. So one thing we've learned from that
is a lot of times when we think

kids are saying a certain thing we think
students are conversing in a certain way even when we're hearing them,
when we record the conversations and

we listen back to it,
that's not actually what happened. And so actually listening and paying
very close attention to where students

are currently in their conversations
is really important, so that you can get them to where
you would like them to be.

And we've created a tool. If I can get this called the conversation
analysis tool that will help you formally

assess the conversation. And this, as you see here on the fly,
this dimension zero, dimension one and

dimension two. So I'm going to talk about dimension
one and dimension two first, because these are the first two

purpose because we want you to be

building up a conversation.

The dimension one, turns build and
previous turns to build up an idea, and by turn,
we mean when one person is talking.

So if Jeff and I were having a conversation right now,
I would say hey, Jeff, how are you doing?

And that would be one turn,
and Jeff may answer me and then that would be a second turn. Now it's his turn.

So dimension one, we say Jeff and I turn we build on each other, so
that we build up an idea over time.

So say our question was
a prompt that we had before. It was Columbus a hero.

And so, I may say I don't
think Columbus is a hero, and just may ask me why
do you not think that?

But it's not unless it's over time
to build up an idea about whether Columbus is or is not a hero.

And then so that's the first one, build up on turns build on each others
build up an idea, and then dimension two,

it turns focus on the content or
skills related to the lessons objectives. So this is not anything new for educators.

Basically, we want to make sure
that students are actually talking about the problems. They're addressing the prompts.

As an early elementary teacher,
this would happen a lot, we'd ask a question about so
what did Tommy do at that birthday party?

And the kids would go off, and I had a

in the realm of birthday parties, but

it's not actually addressing
the prompt the dimension two is, are they actually addressing that?

And one thing that the teachers that

a lot of times we have a ha ha's, and

realize sometimes that our problems that
we're crafting don't necessarily match the objectives that we had.

the students conversation.

That's a dimension one and dimension two. So, dimension zero is students
take appropriate turns.

they're still practicing how to
actually take turns with each other. And so, let's say, and
